original_title: Sri Lanka’s consumer prices up 49.2-pct YoY in March 2023
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s consumer prices, measured by the rebased National Consumer Price Index, were up 49.2 percent from a year earlier, data from the Census and Statistics department showed.
“The reported inflation for the month of March 2023 was mainly due to the higher price levels prevailing in both food and non-food groups,” the department said.
During the month of March, the rebased index rose 0.3 percent to 204.8 points.
The year-on-year food inflation grew to 42.3 percent in March 2023, while the non-food group grew 54.9 percent.
However, according to the rebased index, monthly food prices fell by 2.1 percent, while the non-food prices grew by 2.3 percent.

Sri Lanka’s inflation soared after two years of money printing and a botched float with a surrender rule, which led to a collapse of the rupee from 200 to 360 against the US dollar in the worst currency crisis of the intermediate regime central bank.
However, the rupee started to appreciate after the surrender rule, compelling dollar sales by commercial banks to the central bank, was lifted, giving more dollars to the market in March.

According to the Central Bank governor, Nandalal Weerasinghe, the country expects to have inflation at a single-digit level by the end of the year, helping to bring rates down. (Colombo/April 21/2023)
